Description: Shoulder and body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery hydria; exterior: from top, black-figure decoration consisting of bull (underbelly, with added red, and forelegs remaining) walking to right; narrow dilute brown band at turn to body; black-figure decoration consisting of male figure (only head with red fillet, white outlined eye and ear remaining) to right.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
According to Lamb (p. 41), the figure is that of a woman because of the white flesh. There is no white flesh. Some white outline is visible for the ear and the eye.
Bibliographic references: CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 41, pl. XXI, no. 3)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 295, no. B280 bis)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0932)
